answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
Some sort of communication with those of us that are more technologically savvy would be my recommendation. Also, do something about the slowness of the Knowledge Network, no matter where I log on from and no matter from which of my computers personal or laptops, the loading time is super slow, and it isn't any of my connections.
Maybe do a advertisement in the ICMA literature or the ICMA briefings, that make it easier for everyone to connect. The less barriers you have for someone in the profession to be involved in the knowledge network, the better.

answers.author: Karen Pinkos
answers.text:
Outreach, marketing, communication...keep putting the word out on every conceivable forum, and highlight the areas that people find most useful.  I also think that those of us who are regulars could assist in being ambassadors for the KN to other members.  
Certainly you will have a huge opportunity for marketing the KN at the upcoming conference in tech-savvy San Jose!  You guys are doing a great job, and I'm loving the KN...thanks Tom!

answers.author: Dan Weinheimer
answers.text:
Start 'em young. Do more outreach to Assistants and other journey-level staff who might need to do research on a frequent basis. The more members ask questions the more content you have. The ambassador model can work even better when you have more of them and more questions/content on the network.

text:
ICMA and the Alliance for Innovation is working on the long term strategic plan for the Knowledge Network.  We would like to hear what participants would recommend to expand the number of participants, expand content, enter new markets, partnership possibilities, etc.  
You are all pros at building communities, how would you build the Knowledge Network community?
Post your strategic thoughts here, as answers to this question.
Thanks.
title: What would you do?  To continue to expand the Local Government Knowledge Network.
